elements.content: This work is to emphasize the influence of the synthetic procedures in the isolation of different coordination polymers (CPs) that coexist under hydrothermal conditions, and to determine, both experimental and theoretically, the driving forces that govern the reaction in the YbIII/3,5-DSB/Phen system, to give the following Yb-metal–organic frameworks (MOFs): [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)2(H2O)2]­·(H2O)1/2 (RPF-20-initial) in which all the reactant are stoichiometrically incorporated into the compound; the one-dimensional [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O,(RPF-20-prec), in whose structure hydrogen bonds built up a SP 2-periodic (6,3) Ia supramolecular net; the covalent two-dimensional (2D) [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)]­·H2O, (RPF-20-Yb), with exactly the same (6,3) Ia net topology as its precursor; and the [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)2(OH)3­(H2O)], (RPF-24-Yb) built up from tetranuclear Yb4O14N8 secondary building units. Computational studies have determined the relative energies for the formation of four successively obtained compounds. From the crystallographic (structural and topological) study it is also shown, that it is possible to go from a hydrogen bonded 2D supramolecular net to the covalent one, keeping the topology.

elements.content: This work is to emphasize the influence of the synthetic procedures in the isolation of different coordination polymers (CPs) that coexist under hydrothermal conditions in the YbIII/3,5-DSB/Phen system. The determination of experimental and theoretical driving forces that govern the reaction gives us an idea of what is happening within the hydrothermal system. From structural and topological studies, it is also shown that it is possible to go from a hydrogen-bonded two-dimensional supramolecular net to the covalent one, keeping the net topology.

elements.content: As it is known, subtle modifications in the metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) synthesis variables (temperature, time, pH, solvent, etc.) have a kinetic or thermodynamic effect on the system that ends in different linker and/or metallic connector coordination modes, and thus different nets and topologies. The control in the formation of the polymeric compounds is essential for designing materials with catalytic, magnetic, optic, storage, or separation properties, since these properties directly depend on the dimensionality, topology, coordination environment, or chemical nature of the final network. In a previous work, a new eight-member series RPF-20 (rare earth polymeric framework) (R = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Yb) of two-dimensional (2D) MOFs materials with 3,5-disulfobenzoate (3,5-DSB) and 1,10-phenanthroline was reported; all the MOF materials were obtained as unique phases and tested as acid Lewis heterogeneous catalysts. Our interest being now in carrying out a deeper study on the R/3,5-DSB/Phen system, we chose YbIII as a representative connector and studied the synthetic equilibriums that manage the formation of these MOFs. Four different compounds were achieved: the one-dimensional (1D) [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2­(Phen)4­(H2O)4]­·1/2H2O, RPF-20-initial (from now on), the 1D [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O, RPF-20-prec (from now on), the 2D [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)]­·H2O, RPF-20-Yb and a more condensed 2D phase with tetranuclear SBUs [Yb2(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)2­(OH)3­(H2O)], RPF-24-Yb (from now on).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As it is known, subtle modifications in the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) synthesis variables (temperature, time, pH, solvent, etc.) have a kinetic or thermodynamic effect on the system that ends in different linker and/or metallic connector coordination modes, and thus different nets and topologies. The control in the formation of the polymeric compounds is essential for designing materials with catalytic, magnetic, optic, storage, or separation properties, since these properties directly depend on the dimensionality, topology, coordination environment, or chemical nature of the final network. In a previous work, a new eight-member series RPF-20 (rare earth polymeric framework) (R = Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Yb) of two-dimensional (2D) MOFs materials with 3,5-disulfobenzoate (3,5-DSB) and 1,10-phenanthroline was reported; all the MOF materials were obtained as unique phases and tested as acid Lewis heterogeneous catalysts. Our interest being now in carrying out a deeper study on the R/3,5-DSB/Phen system, we chose YbIII as a representative connector and studied the synthetic equilibriums that manage the formation of these MOFs. Four different compounds were achieved: the one-dimensional (1D) [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2(Phen)4(H2O)4]⋅1/2H2O, RPF-20-initial (from now on), the 1D [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)2]⋅H2O, RPF-20-prec (from now on), the 2D [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)]⋅H2O, RPF-20-Yb and a more condensed 2D phase with tetranuclear SBUs [Yb2(3,5-DSB)(Phen)2(OH)3(H2O)], RPF-24-Yb (from now on).

elements.content: The aim of this work is to emphasize the significance of fine-tuning of the synthetic procedure to obtain each new Yb compound as a separated phase under hydrothermal conditions and to theoretically study the relative energies for those compounds that coexist under certain hydrothermal conditions, knowing in this way the thermodynamic or kinetic control that drives each reaction.
elements.clean_text: The aim of this work is to emphasize the significance of fine-tuning of the synthetic procedure to obtain each new Yb compound as a separated phase under hydrothermal conditions and to theoretically study the relative energies for those compounds that coexist under certain hydrothermal conditions, knowing in this way the thermodynamic or kinetic control that drives each reaction.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used as supplied without further purification: 3,5-disulfobenzoic acid, disodium salt (98%, Sigma-Aldrich); 1,10-phenanthroline (99%, Sigma-Aldrich); Yb­(NO3)3 0.6H2O (99%, Strem Chemicals). The IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000–250 cm–1 on a Bruker IFS 66V/S. The thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyses (TGA-DTA) were performed using a Seiko TG/DTA 320U equipment in a temperature range between 25 and 1000 °C in air (100 mL/min flow) atmosphere and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. A PerkinElmer CNHS Analyzer 2400 was employed for the elemental analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured with a Bruker D8 diffractometer, with a step size 0.02° and exposure time of 0.5 s/step.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used as supplied without further purification: 3,5-disulfobenzoic acid, disodium salt (98%, Sigma-Aldrich); 1,10-phenanthroline (99%, Sigma-Aldrich); Yb(NO3)3 0.6H2O (99%, Strem Chemicals). The IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-250 cm-1 on a Bruker IFS 66V/S. The thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyses (TGA-DTA) were performed using a Seiko TG/DTA 320U equipment in a temperature range between 25 and 1000 °C in air (100 mL/min flow) atmosphere and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. A PerkinElmer CNHS Analyzer 2400 was employed for the elemental analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured with a Bruker D8 diffractometer, with a step size 0.02° and exposure time of 0.5 s/step.

elements.content: After screening the hydrothermal synthesis conditions, the molar composition of the initial reaction mixture in all cases was set as 3,5-DSB3–: Yb3+: 2Phen: 2400H2O. The synthesis procedure in all cases was as follows: 3,5-DSBNa2 (0.073 g, 0.22 mmol) and phenanthroline (0.087 g, 0.44 mmol) were added to a solution of Yb­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.22 mmol) in 10 mL of water; the mixture was magnetically stirred at room temperature for 15 min and then placed into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves for reacting under hydrothermal conditions. After being cooled to room temperature, the crystalline products were filtered and washed with water and acetone. When heating at 60, 70, 80, 100, and 120 °C for 24 h, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2­(Phen)4­(H2O)4]­·1/2H2O (RPF-20-initial) appears. With temperature elevations, namely, at 130 °C, apart from RPF-20-inicial, traces of [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O (RPF-20-prec) appear. In the temperature range 140–200 °C (24 h heating), the main product of the reaction is [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O (RPF-20-prec) together with some small amount of the [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)]­·H2O (RPF-20-Yb). When the reaction time is raised to 3 days, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2­(Phen)2­(H2O)2]­·2H2O (RPF-20-Yb) was obtained. By increasing the temperature to 220 °C and time up to 4 days, [Yb2(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)2­(OH)3­(H2O)] (RPF-24-Yb) was synthesized as an unique phase. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-inicial (C31H24N4O10.5S2Yb): C, 43.40; H, 2.80; N, 6.53; S, 7.47; found: C, 43.52; H, 2.83; N, 6.43; S, 7.44. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-Yb (C38H28N4O19S4Yb2): C, 34.11; H, 2.24; N, 4.19; S, 9.57; found: C, 34.21; H, 2.06; N, 4.25; S, 9.05. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-24-Yb (C31H24N4O12S2Yb2): C, 35.30; H, 2.29; N, 5.31; S, 6.08; found: C, 34.86; H, 2.18; N, 5.33; S, 5.95.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

After screening the hydrothermal synthesis conditions, the molar composition of the initial reaction mixture in all cases was set as 3,5-DSB3-: Yb3+: 2Phen: 2400H2O. The synthesis procedure in all cases was as follows: 3,5-DSBNa2 (0.073 g, 0.22 mmol) and phenanthroline (0.087 g, 0.44 mmol) were added to a solution of Yb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.1 g, 0.22 mmol) in 10 mL of water; the mixture was magnetically stirred at room temperature for 15 min and then placed into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves for reacting under hydrothermal conditions. After being cooled to room temperature, the crystalline products were filtered and washed with water and acetone. When heating at 60, 70, 80, 100, and 120 °C for 24 h, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2(Phen)4(H2O)4]⋅1/2H2O (RPF-20-initial) appears. With temperature elevations, namely, at 130 °C, apart from RPF-20-inicial, traces of [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (RPF-20-prec) appear. In the temperature range 140-200 °C (24 h heating), the main product of the reaction is [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (RPF-20-prec) together with some small amount of the [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)]⋅H2O (RPF-20-Yb). When the reaction time is raised to 3 days, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2(Phen)2(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (RPF-20-Yb) was obtained. By increasing the temperature to 220 °C and time up to 4 days, [Yb2(3,5-DSB)(Phen)2(OH)3(H2O)] (RPF-24-Yb) was synthesized as an unique phase. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-inicial (C31H24N4O10.5S2Yb): C, 43.40; H, 2.80; N, 6.53; S, 7.47; found: C, 43.52; H, 2.83; N, 6.43; S, 7.44. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-Yb (C38H28N4O19S4Yb2): C, 34.11; H, 2.24; N, 4.19; S, 9.57; found: C, 34.21; H, 2.06; N, 4.25; S, 9.05. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-24-Yb (C31H24N4O12S2Yb2): C, 35.30; H, 2.29; N, 5.31; S, 6.08; found: C, 34.86; H, 2.18; N, 5.33; S, 5.95.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data for all the compounds were collected in a Bruker four circle kappa-diffractometer equipped with a Cu INCOATEC microsource operated at 30 W power (45 kV, 0.60 mA) to generated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) and a VANTEC 500 area detector. The unit cell dimension were determined by least-square fitting of reflections with I > 20σ. The structures were solved by direct methods. The final cycles of refinement were carried out by full-matrix least-squares analyses with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were fixed at their calculated positions, except for those of the water molecules that were found in difference Fourier maps. Details for RPF-20 structural type and twin law are in reference X. All calculations were performed using APEX2 software suite for data collection, SAINT for data reduction and SHELXTL to solve and refine the structure. ORTEP diagram, polyhedral and topological representations were prepared with Diamond, Mercury, and Topos software.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray data for all the compounds were collected in a Bruker four circle kappa-diffractometer equipped with a Cu INCOATEC microsource operated at 30 W power (45 kV, 0.60 mA) to generated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) and a VANTEC 500 area detector. The unit cell dimension were determined by least-square fitting of reflections with I > 20σ. The structures were solved by direct methods. The final cycles of refinement were carried out by full-matrix least-squares analyses with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were fixed at their calculated positions, except for those of the water molecules that were found in difference Fourier maps. Details for RPF-20 structural type and twin law are in reference X. All calculations were performed using APEX2 software suite for data collection, SAINT for data reduction and SHELXTL to solve and refine the structure. ORTEP diagram, polyhedral and topological representations were prepared with Diamond, Mercury, and Topos software.

elements.content:
The X-ray powder diffraction measurements were used to check the purity of the obtained microcrystalline products by comparison of the experimental results with the simulated results.

Computational Details

Plane-wave density functional (PW-DF) calculations were done using the VASP package. The energy was calculated employing the generalized gradient approximation, in particular, the exchange and correlation functional of Perdew and Wang (PW91). The effect of the core electrons on the valence electron density was described by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method. The cutoff for the kinetic energy of the plane waves was set to 415 eV throughout, which after extensive tests proved to ensure a total energy convergence better than 10–6 eV. Geometry optimization was carried out using a gradient-conjugate method. The formation energy (ΔE formation) was calculated as the difference between the corresponding energies of the reagents and MOF structures.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction

The X-ray powder diffraction measurements were used to check the purity of the obtained microcrystalline products by comparison of the experimental results with the simulated results.

Computational Details

Plane-wave density functional (PW-DF) calculations were done using the VASP package. The energy was calculated employing the generalized gradient approximation, in particular, the exchange and correlation functional of Perdew and Wang (PW91). The effect of the core electrons on the valence electron density was described by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method. The cutoff for the kinetic energy of the plane waves was set to 415 eV throughout, which after extensive tests proved to ensure a total energy convergence better than 10-6 eV. Geometry optimization was carried out using a gradient-conjugate method. The formation energy (ΔE formation) was calculated as the difference between the corresponding energies of the reagents and MOF structures.

elements.content: Structure consists of octa-coordinated metallic centers in distorted square antiprism (SAPR-8). The YbIII metallic centers are bonded to two phenanthroline molecules, one sulfonate oxygen atom, one carboxylate oxygen atom from two different 3,5-DSB ligand, and two water molecules. An interstitial water molecule is present in the crystalline structure. The 3,5-DSB acts as a bytopic linker in syn η1 coordination mode for carboxilate and sulfonate groups. This arrangement gives rise to chains that run along the [001] direction (Figure a).
elements.clean_text:
[Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)2(H2O)2]⋅1/2H2O RPF-20-init

Structure consists of octa-coordinated metallic centers in distorted square antiprism (SAPR-8). The YbIII metallic centers are bonded to two phenanthroline molecules, one sulfonate oxygen atom, one carboxylate oxygen atom from two different 3,5-DSB ligand, and two water molecules. An interstitial water molecule is present in the crystalline structure. The 3,5-DSB acts as a bytopic linker in syn η1 coordination mode for carboxilate and sulfonate groups. This arrangement gives rise to chains that run along the [001] direction (Figure a).

elements.content: (a) Chains along [001] direction and (b) π–π stacking interactions between the chains for RPF-20-initial.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Chains along [001] direction and (b) π-π stacking interactions between the chains for RPF-20-initial.

elements.content: Every two of these chains are coupled by π–π stacking interactions between the interdigitated phenanthroline rings (distance between centroids = 3.959(1) Å), resulting in double chains along the [100] direction. These double chains are linked by hydrogen bonds between sulfonate oxygen atoms and the interstitial water molecules with a distance O2···O11 = 2.735(2) Å. These interactions give rise to a supramolecular 3D crystal packing (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: Every two of these chains are coupled by π-π stacking interactions between the interdigitated phenanthroline rings (distance between centroids = 3.959(1) Å), resulting in double chains along the [100] direction. These double chains are linked by hydrogen bonds between sulfonate oxygen atoms and the interstitial water molecules with a distance O2⋅⋅⋅O11 = 2.735(2) Å. These interactions give rise to a supramolecular 3D crystal packing (Figure b).

elements.content: Structure is quite similar to the RPF-20-initial, with octa-coordinated metallic centers in distorted square antiprism (SAPR-8). The Yb coordination sphere has one 1,10-phenanthroline molecule, two water molecules, two η2 carboxylate group oxygen atoms, and two oxygen atoms of η1 sulfonate groups in an anti-mode. The 3,5-DSB act thus as a tritopic linker that bonds three YbIII cations along the [110] and [101] directions and gives rise to ladder-shaped polymeric double chains along [110]. It is worth pointing out that in this compound formation, the previous one (RPF-20-initial) loses one phenanthroline molecule, and the linker changes the carboxylate group coordination mode from η1 to η2, and coordinates through the two sulfonate groups becoming a tritopic linker and keeping the Yb octa-coordination.
elements.clean_text:
[Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)2]⋅H2O, RPF-20-prec

Structure is quite similar to the RPF-20-initial, with octa-coordinated metallic centers in distorted square antiprism (SAPR-8). The Yb coordination sphere has one 1,10-phenanthroline molecule, two water molecules, two η2 carboxylate group oxygen atoms, and two oxygen atoms of η1 sulfonate groups in an anti-mode. The 3,5-DSB act thus as a tritopic linker that bonds three YbIII cations along the [110] and [101] directions and gives rise to ladder-shaped polymeric double chains along [110]. It is worth pointing out that in this compound formation, the previous one (RPF-20-initial) loses one phenanthroline molecule, and the linker changes the carboxylate group coordination mode from η1 to η2, and coordinates through the two sulfonate groups becoming a tritopic linker and keeping the Yb octa-coordination.

elements.content: The double chains are linked to each other through hydrogen bonds between one oxygen of the coordinated water molecule and one free oxygen of a sulfonate group (O9–H9B···O2 = 2.8299(7) Å) along the [100] direction (Figure ). This supramolecular junction allows the formation of layers in the plane (110).

This supramolecular junction allows the formation of layers in the plane (110).

elements.content: The compound elongs to a pseudomerohedral twinned crystalline family of isostructural (named RPF-20) compounds previously reported and discussed. In this case the 3,5-DSB anion acts as a tetratopic ligand giving rise to extended layers perpendicular to the [010] direction. Topologically the network has a point symbol (43·63) and is described as an SP 2-periodic net (6,3)­Ia, TOPOS (Figure ). The 3D supramolecular structure is formed through π–π stacking interaction among phenanthroline rings along the [001] direction. In this third stage of the reaction, where pure RPF-20-Yb is obtained (see section), the Yb coordination number is maintained by losing a water molecule and increasing the 3,5-DSB linkage to four, giving rise to the 2D structure, with exactly the same topological net as their precursor the hydrogen bond supramolecular one, the SP 2-periodic net (6,3)­Ia.
elements.clean_text:
[Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)]⋅H2O. RPF-20-Yb

The compound elongs to a pseudomerohedral twinned crystalline family of isostructural (named RPF-20) compounds previously reported and discussed. In this case the 3,5-DSB anion acts as a tetratopic ligand giving rise to extended layers perpendicular to the [010] direction. Topologically the network has a point symbol (43⋅63) and is described as an SP 2-periodic net (6,3)Ia, TOPOS (Figure ). The 3D supramolecular structure is formed through π-π stacking interaction among phenanthroline rings along the [001] direction. In this third stage of the reaction, where pure RPF-20-Yb is obtained (see  section), the Yb coordination number is maintained by losing a water molecule and increasing the 3,5-DSB linkage to four, giving rise to the 2D structure, with exactly the same topological net as their precursor the hydrogen bond supramolecular one, the SP 2-periodic net (6,3)Ia.

elements.content: This compound consists of two crystallographycally independent octa-coordinated YbIII centers in square antiprism (SAPR-8) (YbN2O6) coordination polyhedra (Figure a). The coordination spheres of both Yb1, Yb2 consist of one 1,10-phenanthroline molecule, one carboxylate oxygen atom, other from a sulfonate group both in η1 coordination mode (anti for Yb1, and syn for Yb2), two μ3-OH, two μ-OH, and one water molecule.
elements.clean_text:
[Yb2(3,5-DSB)(Phen)2(μ3-OH)(μ-OH)2H2O)], RPF-24-Yb

This compound consists of two crystallographycally independent octa-coordinated YbIII centers in square antiprism (SAPR-8) (YbN2O6) coordination polyhedra (Figure a). The coordination spheres of both Yb1, Yb2 consist of one 1,10-phenanthroline molecule, one carboxylate oxygen atom, other from a sulfonate group both in η1 coordination mode (anti for Yb1, and syn for Yb2), two μ3-OH, two μ-OH, and one water molecule.

elements.content: The structure is built up by tetranuclear Yb4O14N8 secondary building unit (SBUs) built via μ3- and μ2-hydroxyl groups. The 3,5-DSB ligand acts as a tritopic linker joining the SBUs in the plane (101) (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: The structure is built up by tetranuclear Yb4O14N8 secondary building unit (SBUs) built via μ3- and μ2-hydroxyl groups. The 3,5-DSB ligand acts as a tritopic linker joining the SBUs in the plane (101) (Figure b).

elements.content: Topological analysis shows that the tetranuclear SBUs act as a six-connected node, while the linker connects three SBUs to form a binodal 2D network type kgd Shubnikov plane net with point symbol (43)2(46.66.83) TOPOS (Figure ). Finally, the 3D supramolecular packing is formed by interdigitation of the layer phenanthroline rings via π–π stacking interaction with distance between centroids of 3.7180(2) Å (Figure c).

Finally, the 3D supramolecular packing is formed by interdigitation of the layer phenanthroline rings via π-π stacking interaction with distance between centroids of 3.7180(2) Å (Figure c).

elements.content: Initially the reaction conditions were optimized and fixed at the molar ratio YbIII: 3,5-DSB: 2Phen. We found out that an excess of Phen is needed, since it not only acts as chelating ancillary ligand but also has an influence on the synthesis equilibrium and favors the formation of crystalline pure phases. After the molar ratio was fixed, the effect of temperature, and reaction time was studied with the following results (Figure ):
elements.clean_text:
Effect of the Synthesis Conditions on the Formation of the Four Phases

Initially the reaction conditions were optimized and fixed at the molar ratio YbIII: 3,5-DSB: 2Phen. We found out that an excess of Phen is needed, since it not only acts as chelating ancillary ligand but also has an influence on the synthesis equilibrium and favors the formation of crystalline pure phases. After the molar ratio was fixed, the effect of temperature, and reaction time was studied with the following results (Figure ):

elements.content: (i) Heating of the reaction mixture in the temperature range 60–120 °C results in formation of the monodimensional [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2­(Phen)4­(H2O)4]·H2O, RPF-20-initial, whose formula corresponds exactly to initial system (3,5-DSB3–: Ln3+: 2Phen) stoichiometry, and in whose structure the organic molecule acts as bitopic linker; (ii) when the temperature rises to 130 °C (24 h heating), traces of the monodimensional [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O (RPF-20-prec) appear, being the major product of the reaction RPF-20-init; (iii) in the temperature range 140–200 °C (24 h heating) the compound loses one phenanthroline molecule, and the 3,5-DSB becomes a tritopic linker in the following reaction product: the [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O (RPF-20-prec) together with some traces of the [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)]­·H2O (RPF-20-Yb); (iv) when the time reaction is increased to 3 days (at 200 °C) one coordinated water molecule is lost, the 3,5-DSB goes to tetratopic coordination, and the pure­[Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)]­·H2O RPF-20-Yb is achieved, and (v) by increasing the temperature to 220 °C and time up to 4 days, the 2D [Yb2(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)2­(OH)3­(H2O)], (RPF24) is obtained as unique phase. It is built up from tetranuclear Yb4O14N8 (SBUs) by Yb polyhedra rearrangement, loss of one-half of the linker, and rearrangement of the other half as pentatopic linker and Figures and .

It is built up from tetranuclear Yb4O14N8 (SBUs) by Yb polyhedra rearrangement, loss of one-half of the linker, and rearrangement of the other half as pentatopic linker and Figures  and .

elements.content: It is worth remarking that the RPF-20-precursor is a 1D CP in whose structure the hydrogen bonds built up a SP 2-periodic (6,3) Ia supramolecular net. When the energy increases, the reaction equilibrium displaces toward obtaining of RPF-20-Yb. In its structure one-half of the coordinated water molecules and their corresponding hydrogen bonds vanish, and the 3,5-DSB3– linker becomes tetratopic by coordinating of the sulfonate oxygen atom that was involved in the H-bond (in precursor) to the Yb water vacant position, so that a covalent 2D framework is created with exactly the same (6,3) Ia net topology that the supramolecular one of its precursor. Structurally, it is possible to observe by overlay of RPF-20-Prec and RPF-20-Yb (Scheme ).

elements.content: Recently theoretical calculations have been used as a characterization tool to study the structural stability of crystal phases and their synthesis mechanism during the MOF crystallization. In this work, formation energies (ΔE For) were calculated using the VASP package. The geometry optimization was calculated using the experimental structures data obtained by X-ray diffraction and always converged to a stable structure even though no symmetry constraints were imposed.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

Recently theoretical calculations have been used as a characterization tool to study the structural stability of crystal phases and their synthesis mechanism during the MOF crystallization. In this work, formation energies (ΔE For) were calculated using the VASP package. The geometry optimization was calculated using the experimental structures data obtained by X-ray diffraction and always converged to a stable structure even though no symmetry constraints were imposed.

elements.content: Figure shows the calculated ΔE Formation for each crystal structures normalized to the less stable one. Taking into account these results and the experimental ones (Figure ), it can be concluded that the RPF-20-initial phase is formed during the first stages of the reactions that for temperatures lower than 130 °C are kinetically governed. The temperature increase leads to the formation of RPF-20-prec that can be considered as a precursor of the other two phases (RPF-20-Yb and RPF-24-Yb) which are more energetically stable and their formation is thermodynamically controlled.

elements.content: The influence of the synthetic procedures on the isolation of different CPs that coexist under hydrothermal conditions in the YbIII/3,5-DSB/Phen system has been experimentally and theoretically studied. The relative energies that helped to identify the driving forces for the formation of the four successively obtained phases: RPF-20-initial → RPF-20-prec → RPF-20-Yb → RPF-24-Yb have been calculated.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The influence of the synthetic procedures on the isolation of different CPs that coexist under hydrothermal conditions in the YbIII/3,5-DSB/Phen system has been experimentally and theoretically studied. The relative energies that helped to identify the driving forces for the formation of the four successively obtained phases: RPF-20-initial → RPF-20-prec → RPF-20-Yb → RPF-24-Yb have been calculated.

elements.content: Following the formation of the different CPs by structural studies it has been determined: (i) the Yb cation constant coordination number all over the reaction, (ii) the phenanthroline molecule driving role: it starts being stoichiometrically coordinated in the initial phase, to turn into one-half, which leaves two free coordination Yb sites in the following steps, (iii) the successive increasing of the linker connectivity from 2 up to 5: the 3,5-DSB acts as bitopic, tritopic, tetratopic, and pentatopic linker in the four phases, respectively, and (iv) and most important, it is possible to go from a hydrogen-bonded 2D supramolecular net to a covalent one keeping the net topology.

cln_elements.content: After screening the hydrothermal synthesis conditions, the molar composition of the initial reaction mixture in all cases was set as 3,5-DSB3–: Yb3+: 2Phen: 2400H2O. The synthesis procedure in all cases was as follows: 3,5-DSBNa2 (0.073 g, 0.22 mmol) and phenanthroline (0.087 g, 0.44 mmol) were added to a solution of Yb­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.1 g, 0.22 mmol) in 10 mL of water; the mixture was magnetically stirred at room temperature for 15 min and then placed into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves for reacting under hydrothermal conditions. After being cooled to room temperature, the crystalline products were filtered and washed with water and acetone. When heating at 60, 70, 80, 100, and 120 °C for 24 h, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2­(Phen)4­(H2O)4]­·1/2H2O (RPF-20-initial) appears. With temperature elevations, namely, at 130 °C, apart from RPF-20-inicial, traces of [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O (RPF-20-prec) appear. In the temperature range 140–200 °C (24 h heating), the main product of the reaction is [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)2]­·H2O (RPF-20-prec) together with some small amount of the [Yb­(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)­(H2O)]­·H2O (RPF-20-Yb). When the reaction time is raised to 3 days, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2­(Phen)2­(H2O)2]­·2H2O (RPF-20-Yb) was obtained. By increasing the temperature to 220 °C and time up to 4 days, [Yb2(3,5-DSB)­(Phen)2­(OH)3­(H2O)] (RPF-24-Yb) was synthesized as an unique phase. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-inicial (C31H24N4O10.5S2Yb): C, 43.40; H, 2.80; N, 6.53; S, 7.47; found: C, 43.52; H, 2.83; N, 6.43; S, 7.44. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-Yb (C38H28N4O19S4Yb2): C, 34.11; H, 2.24; N, 4.19; S, 9.57; found: C, 34.21; H, 2.06; N, 4.25; S, 9.05. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-24-Yb (C31H24N4O12S2Yb2): C, 35.30; H, 2.29; N, 5.31; S, 6.08; found: C, 34.86; H, 2.18; N, 5.33; S, 5.95.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

After screening the hydrothermal synthesis conditions, the molar composition of the initial reaction mixture in all cases was set as 3,5-DSB3-: Yb3+: 2Phen: 2400H2O. The synthesis procedure in all cases was as follows: 3,5-DSBNa2 (0.073 g, 0.22 mmol) and phenanthroline (0.087 g, 0.44 mmol) were added to a solution of Yb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.1 g, 0.22 mmol) in 10 mL of water; the mixture was magnetically stirred at room temperature for 15 min and then placed into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves for reacting under hydrothermal conditions. After being cooled to room temperature, the crystalline products were filtered and washed with water and acetone. When heating at 60, 70, 80, 100, and 120 °C for 24 h, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2(Phen)4(H2O)4]⋅1/2H2O (RPF-20-initial) appears. With temperature elevations, namely, at 130 °C, apart from RPF-20-inicial, traces of [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (RPF-20-prec) appear. In the temperature range 140-200 °C (24 h heating), the main product of the reaction is [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (RPF-20-prec) together with some small amount of the [Yb(3,5-DSB)(Phen)(H2O)]⋅H2O (RPF-20-Yb). When the reaction time is raised to 3 days, the pure [Yb2(3,5-DSB)2(Phen)2(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (RPF-20-Yb) was obtained. By increasing the temperature to 220 °C and time up to 4 days, [Yb2(3,5-DSB)(Phen)2(OH)3(H2O)] (RPF-24-Yb) was synthesized as an unique phase. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-inicial (C31H24N4O10.5S2Yb): C, 43.40; H, 2.80; N, 6.53; S, 7.47; found: C, 43.52; H, 2.83; N, 6.43; S, 7.44. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-20-Yb (C38H28N4O19S4Yb2): C, 34.11; H, 2.24; N, 4.19; S, 9.57; found: C, 34.21; H, 2.06; N, 4.25; S, 9.05. Elemental analysis calculated for RPF-24-Yb (C31H24N4O12S2Yb2): C, 35.30; H, 2.29; N, 5.31; S, 6.08; found: C, 34.86; H, 2.18; N, 5.33; S, 5.95.
